Award.AwardTitle: Model inference, comparison, and averaging for genetically structured populations
Award.AbstractNarration:
Researchers collect genetic data to assess variability of animal and plant populations and their ancestral relationships. For such datasets, thousands of different relationships can be specified. For example, are polar bear populations isolated from each other and if not what is the pattern of relationships of polar bears from different populations? This research will develop new methods to calculate the likelihood of different patterns of relationships using Bayesian inference. These methods will be coded into freely available software that will be able to evaluate large data sets. This will achieve accurate ranking of alternative hypotheses using genomic data sets considering complexities such as recombination and data collection artifacts.
This study will provide freely available software along with a user manual for the research community. The new methods will facilitate many types of studies, including disease epidemics, and the studies of the effect of changes in climate onto the distribution and maintenance of genetic variability in crop-related and other species. The software will be disseminated through online tutorials and workshops aimed at senior researchers. There will also be two workshops on computer literacy for individuals ranging from high-school science teachers, to undergraduates, and graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We develop methods for other biologist to analyze sequence data from individuals, such as viruses, bacteria, plants, and animals. These sequences are usually collected at different geographic locations. Our software allows building and testing hypotheses about the interaction of the individuals at these locations. For example, a researcher can test whether two sampling locations belong to one population or two populations. This allows to answer questions about nature reserve size, progress of an epidemic, or historical migration patterns.

This work had three goals. (1) Inclusion of models of population splitting into the  computer program MIGRATE. (2) Explore the bias of estimates of population parameters when recombination in the sequence data is ignored. (3) Distribution of the new methods in a new version of MIGRATE on the website http://popgen.sc.fsu.edu. 

(1) We developed a new model of population splitting. In contrast to earlier methods, this new method treats splitting events on a per individual basis instead of on a population basis. This allows easier estimation of the splitting times using Markov chain Monte Carlo methods than other methods. Previous models included population size and immigration rates. We added now splitting events to estimate population splitting times. The addition of this new module allows a much wider range of hypotheses to assess. We have tested this new module with simulated data to assess correctness of the programming code.

(2) We have explored the effect of using sequence data while ignoring the effects of recombination. Detection of recombination breaks in the sampled sequences is difficult. We described a simple method to explore recombination breaks in the sequence data. For example, one hypothesis or model breaks down the sequence into 5 independent equally long pieces. Another hypothesis breaks down the sequences into 10 equally long pieces. We consider many such hypotheses and evaluate the marginal likelihood of each of these hypotheses. The best hypothesis has the highest marginal likelihood. We used simulated data, and two real datasets to explore which hypotheses should be used for further evaluations. We showed that breaking the sequences into data sets with many small blocks or breaking the sequence into too few pieces leads to biases.  When we use such data to estimate population sizes then the extreme hypotheses overestimate these parameters. Optimal hypotheses, as detected by their marginal likelihood score, have estimates of populations sizes that are smaller than the extreme hypotheses. Our result is interesting because many current methods treat every variable site in the sequence as unlinked or as completely linked data; thus are probably incorrect. 

(3) We have added the population fission model to the program MIGRATE. Researchers can download the new software from our website http://popgen.sc.fsu. The recombination explorations are available as python programs. This program takes the sequence data, generates the different hypotheses, and then evaluates them.

We have presented our research in peer-reviewed publications, at conferences, and invited seminar talks. We taught workshops about how to use our software at several venues during the grant period and will continue to do so. During the awards the PI trained three graduate students and four undergraduate students; all helped to improve this research.
